column2: There are “1.2 million more Canadians working now than ever before.”
column5: All previous periods of employment were not 1.2 million jobs beneath today’s count. The difference in jobs from just before the latest recession to when this claim was made is almost 800,000 jobs.

column2: “The only person on that stage who’s never held a private sector job is Stephen Harper.”
column5: It’s false that Harper never worked a private sector job. After dropping out of the University of Toronto, he took a job with Imperial Oil in the company’s Edmonton office in 1978, leaving in 1981 for a second go at university.

column2: “Our allies have … been clear that Canada should leave our CF-18s in the fight” against Islamic State
column5: The Kurdish government has been critical of Canada’s decision to withdraw its fighter jets. But other major allies in the fight have been agreeable (if vague) about the change, and at least one ally, the United States, has approved.

column2: “While the unemployment rate might be decreasing, the kinds of new jobs created in Canada are part-time.”
column5: The latest job figures show that full-time work is growing more than part-time work in recent months in 2018 and in 2017, compared to the month or year before. There is longer-term and older data that show part-time work has driven total employment growth, but it’s misleading to make a claim about “new jobs” and ignore the latest data.

column2: “Income splitting … will cost the federal government a whopping two billion dollars a year.”
column5: True. Initial estimates peg the cost of income splitting between $2.5 and $2.9 billion, however more recent research estimates a cost of roughly $2 billion per year.

column2: “Stephen Harper is the only prime minister in Canadian history who, when asked about the recession during his mandate, gets to say, ‘Which one?’”
column5: Harper is not the first prime minister to govern over a period with two recessions. Several others did too. Since 1926, there were more prime ministers who held power for over five years who saw at least two recessions than those who did not.

column2: “We’re proud to be the only party making life easier for 100% of families with children.”
column5: While the Conservative Party’s newly expanded Universal Child Care Benefit does appear to benefit 100 per cent of families with children, the NDP would keep the program if elected. The Conservatives’ claim to be the “only party” to benefit everyone is false.

column2: “Mr. Harper promised solemnly to Canadians that he would never name an appointed senator. He has gone on to appoint … them.”
column5: Stephen Harper promised to only appoint people to the Senate who were first elected. He broke the promise by repeatedly appointing unelected senators.

column2: “We are in a world that is becoming increasingly unsafe.”
column5: Stephen Harper said the world is getting increasingly unsafe. Not statistically when it comes to violent deaths. The world is safer today compared to previous decades.

column2: “Canada’s unemployment rate is at its lowest level since the 1970s.”
column5: This is true, but it’s not the first time. Canada’s lowest unemployment rate since the 1970s is 5.8 per cent. Recently, monthly unemployment rates – in December 2017 as well as February-July 2018 – have dipped to 5.8 per cent. Ten years ago and for a shorter period, in October 2007, the rate fell to the same low.

column2: “There are lots of studies that show if you increase the payroll taxes, it leads to employers hiring less people.”
column5: Research does show an increase in payroll taxes will reduce employment. This is expected to be a short-term impact and not severe.

column2: “Under our Conservative government, Canada is going to have virtually unfettered access for our world-class products, workers and investors in 43 countries across the world … compared to just five when we took office.”
column5: The Prime Minister said that with his government, Canada will have free trade with 43 countries. If a concluded agreement with the EU is ratified soon, adding 28 countries to Canada’s current 15 trading partners, this is true.

column2: “There’s nothing in this plan about private sector employment, about job creation.”
column5: The topic of job creation – presumably in the private sector – does make an appearance.

column2: Canada’s corporate tax rate is “way below that of our close trading partners.”
column5: Canada’s combined federal and provincial corporate tax rate of 26.3 per cent is just below the middle of the pack among close trading partners. The corporate tax rate range for Canada’s top ten import and export trading partners is from a low of 16.5 per cent (Hong Kong) to a high of 39 per cent (United States).

column2: “I work hard because millions of people on welfare depend on me.”
column5: The statement “I work hard because millions of people on welfare depend on me” was shared on Facebook 221,467 times. Canada has slightly under two million people on welfare.

column2: “The Security Intelligence Review Committee … is a robust mechanism for independent, expert, third party oversight.”
column5: An oversight mechanism? False. The CSIS Act and SIRC’s last annual report call SIRC a review body (the annual report adds: not an oversight body).

column2: Photo caption “Justin Trudeau meets with Secretary-General of the United Nations Ban Ki-moon.”
column5: That’s not Ban Ki-moon, it’s Jim Kim of the World Bank.

column2: “We take one in ten resettled refugees annually.”
column5: One in ten refugees who go through formal resettlement programs arrived in Canada in 2014. Alexander’s claim is true only for this subset of refugees. People who were resettled last year accounted for less than one per cent of all refugees (0.54 per cent, to be more precise).

column2: The national security watchdog committee can go “wherever the evidence takes them.”
column5: The new committee can track evidence across different departments and agencies. But there are limits on the type of information the committee can access.

column2: “This government committed to ending fossil fuel subsidies.”
column5: The commitment to end fossil fuel subsidies appears in a 2015 statement by leaders of the Group of 20 countries including Canada under Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, and an earlier G20 statement from a 2009 summit. Implementing the G20 commitment is also in the Liberal election platform from 2015. The commitment, however, is about phasing out fossil fuel subsidies over the medium term to 2025.

column2: “The oil sands are about two per cent of GDP.”
column5: It is true the oil sands contribute a direct two per cent to Canada’s GDP, a figure that comes from Statistics Canada. This figure does not include any indirect contributions of the oil sands to related sectors, like construction and finance. By one estimate, the GDP share could rise to six or seven per cent by including indirect contributions in jobs and investment in related sectors.

column2: Harper is “converting the Canadian spy agency into a secret police with virtually unlimited powers.”
column5: The proposed anti-terrorism law, bill C-51, would not give Canada’s spy agency “virtually unlimited powers.” The bill does impose limits on the agency’s powers.

column2: “Trudeau showed up to Washington with … celebrities, his children’s nannies, and his in-laws.”
column5: Yes the trip included family, and a sizeable and high-profile entourage of government ministers too.

column2: “The Minister of Citizenship and Immigration said that the hijab was an indefensible perversion of Canadian values.”
column5: In a case of putting words in someone else’s mouth, Justin Trudeau misquoted or wrongly paraphrased comments by Chris Alexander, giving a false impression of what the immigration minister said.

column2: “The payout to Omar Khadr was a choice made by Justin Trudeau.”
column5: The government had a choice to settle Khadr’s lawsuit or fight it in court. However, according to a few experts, going to court might make political sense but not practical sense. Khadr’s lawsuit followed a Supreme Court decision that found Canadian officials participated in keeping him detained in a foreign prison system that violated his human rights.

column2: “Cnd is 6th largest humanitarian donor in Syria & 5th in Iraq.”
column5: Canada comes in sixth among donor countries for humanitarian spending on the Syrian crisis, and fifth for the Iraqi crisis, according to UN financial tracking. Rob Nicholson’s claim is true.

column2: “The US has a $400-million dairy surplus with Canada.”
column5: The United States sold $376 million more in dairy products to Canada than it purchased in 2016. But a trade surplus isn’t an indicator of more or less open trade. No conclusions can be made about which country is more protectionist using this figure alone.

column2: “There have been more than 40 studies on the plight of murdered and missing aboriginal women.”
column5: Susan Truppe joins fellow MPs claiming there have been 40 studies on murdered and missing aboriginal women. They are correct. At least 58 studies on this topic exist since 1994.

column2: “Canada spends $12 billion a year on oil from Saudi Arabia.”
column5: Canada spends on average $2.2 billion a year on Saudi oil, according to Statistics Canada.

column2: “The past ten years … [was] a period of unprecedented economic instability.”
column5: If we ignore the major (and greater) instability of the Great Depression and look at the intervening years only, the claim is accurate. Although the 2008-2009 recession did not affect Canada as much as the recession in 1981-1982, it caused an upheaval in the global economy from which countries are still recovering at different rates, with an ongoing impact on Canada.

column2: We have “a few dozen soldiers there” in the fight against Islamic State
column5: There are roughly 69 Canadian personnel deployed in Iraq. That could fit within a common understanding of “a few dozen.” But counting those posted in both Kuwait and Iraq as part of the same mission, the number climbs to 669.

column2: The Supreme Court decision on assisted dying talks 17 times about “end-of-life”
column5: Yes, “end-of-life” appears 17 times in the court decision that struck down the ban on physician-assisted dying. But that doesn’t support the government’s position that assisted dying be only for those near death. It appears in an array of different contexts, some relevant, some not.

column2: “What quantum states allow for is much more complex information to be encoded into a single bit.”
column5: A few physicists agree Trudeau’s quantum computing 101 is accurate.

column2: “We know that people are going to spend [child benefit income] on healthier groceries, on school supplies, on summer camp for kids.”
column5: Research on how Canadians spend child tax benefits suggests the money goes to things that enhance children’s wellbeing like food, education, and recreation.

column2: HFCs (hydrofluorocarbons) “are tens of thousands of times more polluting than carbon dioxide.”
column5: Not all hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) are created equal. Some are more harmful than others. On average, HFCs are thousands of times worse for global warming than carbon dioxide. Not “tens of thousands” as McKenna claimed.

column2: “I’m the only Canadian minister who’s been in Syria in four decades.”
column5: Kenney was not the only minister to visit Syria in the last 40 years. Several others did too. Kenney’s office later modified the statement to “the only immigration minister,” which appears to be true.

column2: “In this country, we have zero economic growth.”
column5: Growth was sluggish into 2016, but only below zero in monthly data. Looking at the longer-term picture – measured quarterly and annually – Canada’s growth is above zero.

column2: “Any decision by the B.C. government to limit the flow of bitumen would be outside the province’s jurisdiction.”
column5: The federal government does control interprovincial pipelines. However, provincial governments have shared control of related matters like environmental protection. This means both the federal and provincial governments could potentially impose regulations on a project like the Trans Mountain pipeline expansion. Depending on arguments made by B.C. in an upcoming legal case, there’s at least a chance the courts will find the province has jurisdiction to limit bitumen flow in some capacity.

column2: “In Vancouver now, we have more pot dispensaries than Starbucks locations.”
column5: According to publicly available data, the City of Vancouver has 90 or 91 Starbucks locations and at least 93 marijuana dispensaries. There currently are more marijuana dispensaries than Starbucks locations in Vancouver.

column2: “Seven out of ten working Canadians don’t have a pension.”
column5: This number comes from data covering both the employed and the unemployed available to work. By not using the data on employed Canadians only, Mulcair’s statement is misleading.

column2: “Canada-US relations were so bad in recent years … the old softwood lumber agreement expired.”
column5: The relationship between former Prime Minister Stephen Harper and President Barack Obama may be partly behind the expired softwood lumber deal. But according to experts, several other factors are more likely responsible, such as complexity, lack of incentives on the US side, and the distraction of other mega free trade deals like TPP.

column2: “We’ve got the lowest interest rates in history.”
column5: It’s true we’ve got the lowest interest rates – or cost of government borrowing, measured by bond yields – in a long time.

column2: “We learned with the tragic death of Sgt. Andrew Doiron that [Canadian troops] were indeed on the front line” in Iraq
column5: The death of a Canadian soldier in Iraq was not the first evidence of troops operating at the front lines. That information was already public.

column2: Australian voters have “ballots the size of dorm-room posters.”
column5: Many Australians voted with a ballot measuring over one metre in length to elect senators during the July 2016 election. Ballots for the House of Representatives (equivalent to Canada’s House of Commons), were closer to the size of a leaflet, or roughly the same as Canadian ballots.

column2: Justin Trudeau and Tom Mulcair “threaten to take this [TFSA] option away from Canadians.”
column5: The Conservative Party’s claim that TFSAs are under threat by the NDP and Liberal Party is ambiguously worded. While it is true that both parties pledged to roll back recent increase to contribution limits, they have also committed to keeping the program in place. The vague language used by the Conservatives could easily give the impression their opponents would scrap the whole TFSA.

column2: “It is an obligation of an MP to present every petition submitted to them”
column5: Elizabeth May said MPs have an “obligation” to present petitions. The House rule book says they do not.

column2: “Never in the history of Canada has a drug become a medicine because a judge has deemed it so.”
column5: It’s true that courts do not turn drugs into medicine. And keeping with history, contrary to what is being implied, the court did not do this in the latest ruling on marijuana.

column2: In Saudi Arabia, “what’s changed … is these beheadings, and particularly of a religious cleric.”
column5: While some facts about the January executions of 47 people are different, like the number of deaths and the profile of one person killed, experts say this is not new policy or a new trend, and not an event that came without warning.

column2: In early 2015, Canada’s “economy is not performing well compared to the rest of the world.”
column5: Canada’s economic performance, considered in terms of GDP growth in the first quarter of 2015, does not measure well compared to the economies of the United States, United Kingdom, Germany, Australia, the G7, and the G20 in the same period.

column2: “For the first time in our country’s history, we are making these letters public.”
column5: Releasing mandate letters is not unprecedented in Canadian politics. Provincial governments have done it before. But it is a first for the feds, so in that context, Trudeau’s statement is true.

column2: “The Conservatives’ recent budget made no mention of climate change.”
column5: It is true the budget does not contain the term “climate change,” but it is misleading to claim that the budget ignores the subject entirely. There is a close reference, plus funding for projects to reduce GHG emissions.

column2: “We have lost a Canadian soldier behind enemy lines” in Iraq
column5: The first Canadian killed in the U.S.-led coalition fight against Islamic State in Iraq did not die behind enemy lines. The incident occurred on Kurdish-held territory in Northern Iraq.

column2: “This is the first government in Canadian history that, faced with a recession, did not cut our immigration.”
column5: This is not the first government in Canadian history to keep immigration uncut during a recession. During the 1990-1991 recession in Canada, the Mulroney government increased the annual immigration level.

column2: “Five million Canadians don’t have a family doctor.”
column5: The number of Canadians without a doctor ranges between 4.6 million and 5.6 million, depending on the survey. According to one survey, a large portion of those were not looking for a family doctor.

column2: “Canadians are already footing the bill for Harper’s early election call – as much as a billion dollars.”
column5: While a longer than expected campaign period of 78 days will come with a larger than predicted price tag, it is unlikely that the total cost of the election will approach $1 billion. The NDP counted all costs as variable, instead of both variable and fixed, to arrive at that figure. As for a more logically correct estimate, Elections Canada is still working it out.

column2: Supreme Court judges “think that they can approve a drug into a medicine, without clear clinical scientific evidence, and without safety reviews.”
column5: The Supreme Court of Canada did not approve marijuana into a medicine. It found that prohibiting non-dried forms of medical marijuana violates the Charter.

column2: “Family reunification … [has] been completely shut down under Mr. Harper’s Conservatives.”
column5: While changes to Canada’s family immigration stream may make it harder for certain family groups to immigrate to Canada, the stream has not completely shut down (in 2014, 66,659 people got permanent residence through the family stream). Nor have overall levels of family immigration significantly changed under the Harper government.

column2: “Canada went from 2.5 million protected lakes and rivers, down to just 159 under the Conservatives.”
column5: There are now 159 lakes and rivers, plus 3 oceans, in Canada that are considered protected in the Navigation Protection Act (NPA). That is down from an estimated 2.5 million. However, protection here refers to keeping a water body useable for commerce or travel. While conditions for federal environmental oversight have also changed, they don’t have much to do with the NPA and the number 159.

column2: “Bill C-42 would allow handguns and assault weapons to be freely transported … even left parked outside a Canadian Tire or local hockey arena.”
column5: Justin Trudeau said bill C-42 to amend the Firearms Act would allow “handguns and assault weapons” to be transported anywhere within a province, even to Canadian Tire or a hockey arena. This is false. The locations that were unlawful before, continue to be unlawful.

column2: “Taxes were lowered for middle-class Canadians.”
column5: The Liberal government and key departments refuse to clearly define who’s in the “middle class,” so can’t claim to benefit them.

column2: “Canada is the only country in the world to have withdrawn from the Kyoto Protocol.”
column5: Of the 192 parties to the Kyoto Protocol, Canada is the only country with a small “w” beside its name to indicate “withdrawal.”

column2: Tom Mulcair “changed his mind, and he wants us to use our majority to ram through electoral change.”
column5: Mulcair has been consistent that all parties should be involved in introducing a new voting system.

column2: “We have seen since the great global financial crisis, Canada has the strongest economic growth, the strongest job creation record and the strongest income growth for the middle class among any of the major developed economies.”
column5: Between the second quarter of 2009, the trough of the financial crisis, and the first quarter of 2015, it is true that Canada outperformed its peers in the G7 in economic growth and in the number of jobs created. Due to a lack of comparative data on median household incomes across the G7 over the same period, we are withholding judgment on Harper’s claim that Canada has also led the G7 in middle class income growth.

column2: “When you have a contingency that is not used, it goes to repay debt … That’s what happens automatically at the end of the year.”
column5: Canadian governments, dating at least to the Jean Chrétien era, have kept a contingency fund in one form or another which, if unused, helps reduce the debt.

column2: “Tax exemptions given to web giants … cost Canadians nearly $1B every year in lost tax revenue.”
column5: The “tax exemption” at the center of this check is about the collection of sales taxes. Because tax laws were written before online sales, foreign web companies don’t always have to collect taxes like domestic counterparts do. If collected, those taxes may equal $1 billion or more. However, the claim omits that the taxes in question would be paid by Canadians, and we find that misleading.

column2: “Everybody has some sort of ID to show who they are.”
column5: By default of being born in Canada or immigrating, and accessing a range of basic services, it is true that we’ve all very likely been issued ID at some point, but it’s simplistic to assume everyone still has ID. And in the context of voting, Poilievre’s statement is misleading. In order to vote, people need to prove both who they are and where they live.

column2: The Liberals offered “classes for returning terrorists in poetry and podcasting, not to mention cheques for $10 million.”
column5: The government does provide funding for at least one program that uses podcasting and poetry to help prevent radicalization. However, the program at issue, developed by Project SOMEONE, is not offered to returning fighters.

column2: “It took [Harper] only three years to put Canada back into deficit, and that was ahead of the recession.”
column5: The first federal deficit under Stephen Harper was logged for April 2008 to March 2009, overlapping with the Canadian onset of the recent global recession sometime between October 2008 and March 2009.

column2: “We will have reached the number 25,000 and thereby kept our promise.”
column5: The Liberals originally promised 25,000 government-sponsored refugees by the end of 2015. The new commitment is a total of 25,000 government-sponsored refugees by the end 2016, which substantially alters the promise.

column2: “Bill C-51 does not add new powers to CSIS, it adds new powers to our independent judiciary, to the courts, to judges.”
column5: Jason Kenney said his government’s proposed anti-terrorism bill does not give new powers to CSIS. This is false. CSIS gets new powers under C-51.

column2: “The current ministry has swelled to 39 members, by far the largest cabinet in the democratic world.”
column5: The cabinets of the world’s democratic countries are smaller than the current Canadian one.

column2: “400,000 manufacturing jobs have been lost in Canada since 2004 … 50,000 just in the auto sector alone.”
column5: Nathan Cullen said that since 2004, 400,000 manufacturing jobs were lost in Canada, 50,000 of those in the automotive sector. This is true, and part of a trend that is not confined to Canada.

column2: “The OECD has said that Canada is the third worst country in the world for crappy jobs.”
column5: Liberal MP Ralph Goodale said the OECD listed Canada as the third worst country in the world for “crappy jobs.” This is false. The rank comes from Morgan Stanley economists. The OECD uses a more comprehensive analysis of job quality where Canada scored middle of the pack.

column2: “On July 20 the biggest single benefit in Cdn history will be distributed to families across Cda.”
column5: The UCCB money totalling $3 billion delivered in July is not the biggest individual payment, total payment, or even same-day payment in the history of Canadian benefits.

column2: “Omar Khadr didn’t apologize.”
column5: Omar Khadr apologized to the widow of Christopher Speer, the U.S. soldier killed in Afghanistan in a disputed firefight, at a military commission trial in Guantanamo Bay in 2010. More recently, he apologized to the Speer family for any pain caused by talk of a settlement with the Canadian government.

column2: “You have to commit a criminal offence” to fall within the scope of C-51 powers
column5: According to Daryl Kramp, only criminal offences fall within the scope of the government’s proposed anti-terrorism bill. That’s not what the bill says.

column2: Canada’s emissions target is “incompatible with the Paris Agreement”
column5: Canada’s target is allowed by the terms of the agreement. But to meet the agreement’s goal of limiting global temperature rise to 2 degrees Celsius or less, Canada and all countries combined need higher targets.

column2: “By denying climate change, [Stephen Harper] denied Canadians opportunity.”
column5: Harper is not a climate change denier. The prime minister has made multiple statements over his time in office calling climate change real and urgent.

column2: The Canada Child Benefit “has lifted hundreds of thousands of children out of poverty.”
column5: The number of children lifted out of poverty by the Canada Child Benefit won’t be known until late 2017 or early 2018.

column2: “Harper reportedly held just three press conferences in the theatre.”
column5: Stephen Harper used the National Press Theatre seven times between 2006 and 2009, not three, as reported by the Huffington Post.

column2: “Detain, question, and return – it’s that simple.”
column5: Under Canadian law, it’s not always possible to detain or remove irregular border crossers from Canada. Detention and removal can happen, but with many steps in between. It’s not so simple as “detain, question, and return.”

column2: Young women “account for a shocking 74 per cent of all new HIV infections among adolescents in Africa.”
column5: Data from UNAIDS and UNICEF shows that young girls aged 10 to 19 in sub-Saharan Africa are significantly more vulnerable to HIV infection than their male peers due to a variety of economic and gender-related factors.

column2: “The Conservatives’ decision to raise the eligibility age for old age security and the guaranteed income supplement to 67 … will cost our most vulnerable seniors $32,000.”
column5: At the current maximum payout rates, two lost years of OAS and GIS could cost roughly $32,000.

column2: Canada’s federal corporate tax rate is “about 12, 13 [per cent].”
column5: Canada’s corporate tax rate is 15 per cent. Mulcair was off by 2-3 per cent, and later acknowledged his mistake.

column2: “Back in 2008, Mr. Harper was misleading. He said that we were not in a recession and in fact it turned out we were in the worst recession since the 1920s.”
column5: Stephen Harper said Canada was not in recession as late as October 2008, but changed his outlook by the end of November 2008. The start date of the 2008 global recession in Canada is pegged at sometime between October 2008 and March 2009. Depending on the analysis, the denial came just before or right at the start of the recession.

column2: Flaherty told Ontarians they had “no one to blame but themselves” for losing manufacturing jobs
column5: Justin Trudeau used a statement by Jim Flaherty out of context to suggest the then-finance minister blamed Ontarians for the province losing manufacturing jobs. Flaherty said no such thing.

column2: “This Prime Minister has the worst rate of export growth of any prime minister since World War II.”
column5: It is true Stephen Harper’s government saw the lowest average annual growth in exports since 1946. But this is not the same thing as finding he is at fault for that record. A few experts argue he is not.

column2: “We have aircraft strafing” in Iraq
column5: Canadian aircraft did not engage in strafing in Iraq as Mulcair claimed. They dropped bombs, but did not engage in the more dangerous act of flying low to fire on ground targets known as strafing.

column2: “In total, this week’s trip has yielded more than $1 billion in investment between Canada and India.”
column5: The agreements totaling $1 billion did not happen because of Justin Trudeau’s week-long trip to India. Some investment announcements coincided with the trip, but the deals behind the majority of the investment figure were signed or proposed weeks to months before. Plus, attributing long-term investment to a single state visit is shaky logic.
